citeinfo.title: Carbon budget assessment of tidal freshwater forested wetland and oligohaline marsh ecosystems along the Waccamaw and Savannah rivers, U.S.A. (2005-2016)

descript.abstract: Data to support carbon (C) budget assessment of tidal freshwater forested wetland and oligohaline marsh ecosystems along the Waccamaw and Savannah rivers, U.S.A. This work represents the first estimates of C standing stocks, C mass balance, soil C burial, and lateral C export to aquatic environments in tidal freshwater forested wetlands undergoing transition to oligohaline marsh.
descript.purpose: Data were collected to assess organic carbon (C) standing stocks, C mass balance, and soil C burial as wetland ecosystems transition from tidal freshwater forested wetlands to low-salinity marshes.
descript.supplinf: Author ORCIDs: Krauss, K.W.(0000-0003-2195-0729);Noe, Gregory(0000-0002-6661-2646);Jones, M.C.(0000-0002-6650-7619);Bernhardt, C.E.(0000-0003-0082-4731);Cormier, Nicole(0000-0003-2453-9900);From, Andrew(0000-0002-6543-2627) We have included several statements concerning the ethical use of this dataset. We adopted the following statement regarding data archiving and sharing from Wright et al. (2004): "The authors believe that the archiving and sharing of large datasets is important for advancing ecology as a discipline. At the same time, for data sharing to be successful and sustainable, it is imperative that all those involved in data acquisition, archiving and use do so in an ethical manner. In particular, we believe that those individuals whose time, efforts and intellect designed and created the studies are acknowledged appropriately." Text in quotation from: Wright, I. J., P. B. Reich, M. Westoby, D. D. Ackerly, Z. Baruch, F. Bongers, J. Cavender-Bares, T. Chapin, J. H. Cornelissen, and M. Diemer. 2004. The worldwide leaf economics spectrum. Nature 428:821-827. As a condition for use of this dataset, users agree: (1) To notify the USGS lead investigator (Ken W. Krauss, U.S. Geological Survey, kraussk@usgs.gov) if the dataset is to be used in any publication; (2) To provide formal recognition that, at our discretion, may include co-authorship or acknowledgements on publications; (3) To recognize that we may be using these data for scientific analyses, papers or publications that are currently planned or in preparation, and that such activities have precedence over any that that you might wish to prepare.

spdom.descgeog: Waccamaw and Savannah rivers, South Carolina and Georgia

taxonsys.taxoncom: Expert knowledge of the local plant community was used for species identifications.

taxonomy.taxongen: All plants were identified to the level of Species or Genus in the data.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

method.methdesc: Tree and shrub surveys were conducted according to the USGS Climate and Land Use Change R&D project study sites along the Savannah and Waccamaw rivers, originally described in Krauss et al. 2009 (Wetlands, vol. 29, 5p. 05-519). Since, Marsh sites were added, but they have no forest structural data to report as they are Marsh. Herbaceous data from the Marsh sites reported herein were from Ensign et al. 2014 (Estuaries and Coasts, vol. 37, p. 1107-1119), and listed in that report as “Waccamaw Oligohaline marsh” and “Savannah Oligohaline marsh”. Methods of calculating carbon biomass for trees followed Jenkins et al. 2003 (Forest Science, vol. 49, p. 12-35) because we do not have information regarding % cull or individual tree heights. For the journal article, biomass methods of trees 2.5 cm and larger follow Jenkins et al 2003 (Forest Science, vol. 49, p. 12-35). Biomass methods of trees smaller than 2.5 cm DBH follow Day and Monk 1974 (Ecology, vol. 55, p. 1064-1074). Litterfall data from 2005-2009 were previously published in Cormier et al. 2013 (Estuaries and Coasts, vol. 36, p. 533-546). Wood biomass increment was determined by assessing annual individual tree diameter change following the methods of Megonigal et al. 1997 (Ecology, v. 78, p. 370-384). Root ingrowth data represent ingrowth of roots into root-free cores over the course of one year. These data were used at face value for the Savannah River, but averaged with Pierfelice et al. 2017 (Journal of Hydrologic Engineering, v. 22, D5015002) for the Waccamaw River. Greenhouse gas data represent raw individual chamber-based values from Krauss and Whitbeck 2012 (Wetlands, v. 32, p. 73-81), which were used to determine soil C fluxes from Savannah River Upper, Middle, and Lower sites, and used to estimate soil C fluxes from Savannah River Marsh. Percent carbon data were derived from an elemental analyzer and were used to derive %C vs LOI relationship, to derive %C for remaining samples, and calculate C accumulation rates. After data entry all datasets were reviewed for QA/QC.

procstep.procdesc: Datasets were created using data collected in the field and in the lab.

enttyp.enttypd: Tree and shrub surveys were conducted according to the USGS Climate and Land Use Change R&D project study sites along the Savannah and Waccamaw rivers, originally described in Krauss et al. 2009 (Wetlands, vol. 29, 5p. 05-519). Since, Marsh sites were added, but they have no forest structural data to report as they are Marsh. Herbaceous data from the Marsh sites reported herein were from Ensign et al. 2014 (Estuaries and Coasts, vol. 37, p. 1107-1119), and listed in that report as “Waccamaw Oligohaline marsh” and “Savannah Oligohaline marsh”. Methods of calculating carbon biomass for trees followed Jenkins et al. 2003 (Forest Science, vol. 49, p. 12-35) because we do not have information regarding % cull or individual tree heights. For the journal article, biomass methods of trees 2.5 cm and larger follow Jenkins et al 2003 (Forest Science, vol. 49, p. 12-35). Biomass methods of trees smaller than 2.5 cm DBH follow Day and Monk 1974 (Ecology, vol. 55, p. 1064-1074).

attr.attrdef: If tree is alive and tree DBH is ≥ 10 cm, tree is tagged with a numbered aluminum tag having this value.

edom.edomvd: Indicates tree was not given an aluminum tag

attr.attrdef: Species of tree surveyed depicted by common name. Common name to scientific name conversions are presented below. See taxonomy section of this metadata record for additional taxonomic details.

Denotes whether a tree is live or dead

Wood biomass increment was determined by assessing annual individual tree diameter change following the methods of Megonigal et al. 1997 (Ecology, v. 78, p. 370-384).

edom.edomvd: Healthy tidal freshwater forested wetland sites (salinity, 0.1 psu)
Moderately salinity stressed forested wetland sites (salinity, 1.2-1.4 psu)

attr.attrdef: Number of the paired plot on each site from which these data were collected (1 or 2); Each plot is 20 x 25 m in area.
Line-intercept transect lines established in random azimuths, each 20 m long.
Compass azimuth of 20-m line-intercept transects.
Count of line-intercepted wood in the 0-1 cm diameter class (within first 2 meter of transect)
Count of line-intercepted wood in the 1-2.5 cm diameter class (within first 4 meter of transect)
Count of line-intercepted wood in the 2.5-7.5 cm diameter class (within first 4 meter of transect)
For wood ≥7.5 cm, actual diameter of recently fallen and relatively firm downed wood on soil surface, or elevated no more than 1 m from surface
For wood ≥7.5 cm, actual diameter of older downed wood on soil surface not easily penetrated by caliper (on surface or less than 1 m from surface)
For wood ≥7.5 cm, actual diameter of older downed wood on soil surface easily penetrated by caliper (on surface or less than 1 m from surface)

enttyp.enttypd: These data represent ingrowth of roots into root-free cores over the course of one year. These data were used at face value for the Savannah River, but averaged with Pierfelice et al. 2017 (Journal of Hydrologic Engineering, v. 22, D5015002) for the Waccamaw River.

Root class (Lf = Live Fine roots < 2 mm diameter; Lx = Live Coarse roots > 2 mm diamater; D = Dead roots in all size classes)

edom.edomvd: Dead roots in all size classes

attr.attrdef: Root productivity (determined by all roots in those categories growing into a root-free bag over one year)
